title: Synthetic Recap
body:
In a performance for the ages, Jayson Williams refused to let the New Jersey Nets lose.

On a night defined by one man’s historic dominance on the glass, the Nets outlasted the rival New York Knicks, 103-98. The final score was merely a formality; the true story was written in the stat sheet, where Williams authored a rebounding masterpiece.

The Nets’ center was an unstoppable force of will and energy, corralling a monstrous **27 rebounds** to go with his 18 points. He was a one-man wrecking crew, controlling the paint and denying the Knicks any semblance of a second chance. His relentless effort on the boards was the cornerstone of the entire contest, turning potential Knicks possessions into transition opportunities for New Jersey.

While Williams dominated the interior, Kendall Gill provided the offensive firepower, leading all scorers with 28 points. Keith Van Horn added a solid 20-point contribution, but this night belonged to his frontcourt partner. For the Knicks, Allan Houston fought valiantly, scoring 26 points, but his team was systematically dismantled by Williams’ singular focus.

Every time the Knicks threatened to close the gap, a Williams rebound—be it a crucial defensive board or a momentum-shifting offensive putback—snuffed out their rally. It was a throwback, blue-collar performance that propelled the Nets to a hard-fought victory and etched Jayson Williams’ name into the franchise record books with a night of pure, unadulterated hustle.
